children.subject: (I guess it is not necessarily an undergraduate class though, given that it's a graduate level course)
CS 285, maybe? Heard from a friend that you do something along those lines for a final project. However, to get in, I think you need A/A- in 189, 126 and 127. Maybe someone can corroborate.

In EE106B the final project is of a level of a research paper. Basically you do research and have to submit a paper very similar to research paper (by similar I mean if you spent a couple more months on it, then it would be appropriate for submission to a conference like ICRA). It’s a robotics course so the paper would have to relate to something in robotics. It’s recommended to take EE106A first though.

A lot of graduate-level courses entail a final research project (the ones I've taken are CS 262A and two EE 290 special topics classes). While they're not usually at a publishable level, many students continue with those projects after the class ends and publish them eventually. I'd recommend looking through the grad courses and email the instructors of those you're interested in to see what their admissions policies for undergrads are!

history.content:
Dear EECS 101,

Are there any research-based undergraduate classes in EECS (i.e. classes where students do a research project that gets published or is at least appropriate for a CV)? How do I get into those classes?

Thank You,

Ryota Inagaki
history.subject: Research Classes
